questions.title: Read the poem and answer the questions that follow.

passage.title: The Country Mouse and the City Mouse
passage.content:
In a snug little cot lived a fat little mouse,
Who enjoyed, unmolested, the range of the house;
With plain food content, she would breakfast on cheese,
She dined upon bacon, and supped on grey peas.

A friend from the town to the cottage did stray,
And he said he was come a short visit to pay;
So the mouse spread her table as gay as you please,
And brought the nice bacon and charming grey peas.

The visitor frowned, and he thought to be witty:
Cried he, "You must know, I come from the city,
Where we all should be shocked at provisions like these,
For we never eat bacon and horrid grey peas."

passage.title: How Driverless Cars will Change our World
passage.content:
It's a late night in the Metro area of Phoenix, Arizona. Under the artificial glare of street lamps, a car can be seen slowly approaching. Active sensors on the vehicle radiate a low hum. A green and blue 'W' glows from the windscreen, giving off just enough light to see inside - to a completely empty driver seat.

The promise of driverless technology has long been enticing. It has the potential to transform our experience of commuting and long journeys, take people out of high-risk working environments and streamline our industries. It's key to helping us build the cities of the future, where our reliance and relationship with cars are redefined lowering carbon emissions and paving the way for more sustainable ways of living.

But in order for driverless technology to become mainstream, much still needs to change. "Driverless vehicles should be a very calm and serene way of getting from A to B. But not every human driver around it will be behaving in that way," says David Hynd. "It's got to be able to cope with human drivers speeding, for instance, or breaking the rules of the road." And that's not the only challenge. There's regulation, rethinking the Highway Code, public perception, and the big question of ultimate liability for road accidents.

passage.title: STAFF WANTED
passage.content:
The Himalayan Grill, a new fine-dining restaurant in Kathmandu, is seeking enthusiastic and dedicated individuals to join our team.

1. Waiter/Waitress - 5 Positions
- Requirements: At least 1 year of experience in a similar restaurant. Excellent communication and customer service skills. Must be fluent in English.
- Age: Not exceeding 30 years.

2. Kitchen Helper - 3 Positions
- Requirements: High school graduate. Must be hardworking, willing to learn, and able to work in a fast-paced environment. Prior kitchen experience is a plus but not required.
- Note: Candidates must be willing to work flexible hours, including evenings and weekends.

3. Accountant - 1 Position
- Requirements: Bachelor's Degree in Commerce or Accounting. At least 2 years of work experience with knowledge of VAT and tax systems. Proficient in accounting software.

Interested candidates are requested to submit their application along with a detailed CV and a passport-sized photograph to the restaurant's office by 15th April, 2025.

The Himalayan Grill
Thamel, Kathmandu, Nepal
Email: careers@himalayangrill.com.np

(The restaurant reserves the right to reject any or all applications without assigning any reason whatsoever.)

passage.title: London vs Paris
passage.content:
While London is the capital of the United Kingdom, it is also the largest city in the country. Paris, on the other hand, is the capital city of France. Both cities have a rich history and are global centres for culture, fashion, and art.

London is among the largest metropolitan areas in Europe, covering an estimated area of 1,572 square kilometers. Paris covers an estimated 105 square kilometres. Although Paris is smaller in terms of area, the city happens to be one of the most densely populated cities in Europe.

These cultural differences mainly stem from the cultural difference between England and France. For instance, in England, a handshake is the standard way to greet a person. The French accept a handshake although a kiss is a conventional way of saying hello. In terms of the language, the French are quite protective of their language. Therefore, while in Paris, try to speak some French.

Both London and Paris are known for their high cost of living, but London is quite more expensive than Paris. However, groceries and other consumer prices are lower in London. In other aspects such as local transportation costs, Paris appears to be quite cheaper. Paris will be a great option if you are looking for a pocket-friendly destination.

questions.title: Write a set of rules and regulations to be followed in a computer lab.

sampleAnswer.title: Computer Lab Rules and Regulations
sampleAnswer.content: To ensure a productive and safe environment for all users, please adhere to the following rules. Firstly, no food or drinks are allowed near the computers to prevent accidental spills and damage. Always save your work frequently to avoid losing data. Students are strictly prohibited from installing any unauthorized software or changing system settings. Please keep your workstation clean and tidy before you leave. After finishing your work, you must log out properly from your account. If you encounter any hardware or software problems, please do not attempt to fix them yourself; report them immediately to the lab in-charge.

questions.title: Write a message of sympathy to your friend whose grandmother has recently passed away. Write it in about 100 words.
clues: thinking of you and your family

sampleAnswer.content:
Dear Anjali,

I was deeply saddened to hear about the passing of your grandmother. I am so sorry for your loss. I know how close you were to her, and I can only imagine the pain you and your family are going through right now.

I will always remember her as a very kind and loving person. I have fond memories of her telling us stories when we were children. She will be greatly missed.

Please know that I am thinking of you during this difficult time. If there is anything at all I can do to help, please do not hesitate to ask. 

With deepest sympathy,
Sunita

questions.title: Write a dialogue between two friends who are discussing the advantages and disadvantages of online classes. Write it in at least six exchanges.

sampleAnswer.content:
Rina: Hi Sameer! How are you finding the online classes?

Sameer: Hi Rina! Well, they are convenient. I like that I can attend from home and save travel time. What about you?

Rina: I agree, the flexibility is a big advantage. I can re-watch the recorded lectures if I miss something. But I find it hard to stay focused sometimes. There are so many distractions at home.

Sameer: That's true. I also miss the classroom interaction. It's not the same asking questions through a chatbox. I feel we learn more when we discuss things with friends and teachers in person.

Rina: Exactly! And the practical subjects are very difficult to understand online. We can't do experiments or hands-on activities. It's all theoretical.

Sameer: You're right. So, while online classes have their benefits, I think they can't completely replace the experience of being in a real classroom.

questions.title: Write a review of a book you have recently read in about 200 words. Include its title, author, a brief summary, and your recommendation.

sampleAnswer.title: Book Review: 'The Alchemist' by Paulo Coelho
sampleAnswer.content:
'The Alchemist' by Paulo Coelho is a truly inspiring novel that takes the reader on a profound journey of self-discovery. The story follows a young Andalusian shepherd boy named Santiago, who travels from his homeland in Spain to the Egyptian desert in search of a treasure buried near the Pyramids.

The plot is simple yet powerful. Along his journey, Santiago meets several interesting characters, including a king and an alchemist, who guide him and teach him important lessons about listening to his heart, following his dreams, and understanding the language of the universe. The core message of the book is that when you truly want something, the entire universe conspires in helping you to achieve it. This theme of following one's 'Personal Legend' is beautifully woven throughout the narrative.

The strength of the book lies in its simplicity and its universal appeal. Coelho's writing is lyrical and full of wisdom, making it a quick but deeply moving read. While some might find the story a bit too philosophical, its message is timeless and uplifting.

I would highly recommend 'The Alchemist' to anyone who is at a crossroads in their life or is looking for a dose of inspiration. It is a book that encourages you to believe in your dreams and to have the courage to pursue them, no matter the obstacles.

questions.title: Reproduce the following sentences as instructed in the brackets.

subQuestions.questionEnglish: Someone is waiting for you, .............? (Add a correct question tag.)
subQuestions.correctAnswer: Someone is waiting for you, aren't they?
subQuestions.explanation:
Explanation (English): The subject 'Someone' is indefinite and is replaced by 'they' in the tag question. When 'they' is the pronoun, the verb 'are' is used. The statement is positive, so the tag is negative.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): 'Someone' अनिश्चित सर्वनाम हो र ट्याग प्रश्नमा 'they' ले प्रतिस्थापन गर्दछ। जब 'they' सर्वनाम हुन्छ, क्रिया 'are' प्रयोग हुन्छ। वाक्य सकारात्मक भएकोले, ट्याग नकारात्मक हुन्छ।

subQuestions.questionEnglish: He said, "I have finished my homework." (Change into indirect speech.)
subQuestions.correctAnswer: He said that he had finished his homework.
subQuestions.explanation:
Explanation (English): In reported speech, the present perfect tense ('have finished') changes to the past perfect tense ('had finished'). The pronouns 'I' and 'my' change to 'he' and 'his' respectively.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): रिपोर्टेड स्पीचमा, present perfect tense ('have finished') past perfect tense ('had finished') मा परिवर्तन हुन्छ। सर्वनाम 'I' र 'my' क्रमशः 'he' र 'his' मा परिवर्तन हुन्छन्।

subQuestions.questionEnglish: People speak English all over the world. (Change into passive voice.)
subQuestions.correctAnswer: English is spoken all over the world.
subQuestions.explanation:
Explanation (English): The sentence is in the simple present tense. The passive form is 'object + is/am/are + V3'. The agent 'by people' is omitted because it is obvious.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): वाक्य simple present tense मा छ। यसको passive form 'object + is/am/are + V3' हो। 'by people' लाई हटाइएको छ किनभने यो स्पष्ट छ।

subQuestions.questionEnglish: She is too weak to walk. (Change using 'so that'.)
subQuestions.correctAnswer: She is so weak that she cannot walk.
subQuestions.explanation:
Explanation (English): The structure 'too...to' can be rewritten using 'so...that'. 'Too' is replaced by 'so', and 'to' is replaced by 'that' followed by a clause that expresses the result.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): 'too...to' को संरचनालाई 'so...that' प्रयोग गरेर पुनर्लेखन गर्न सकिन्छ। 'Too' लाई 'so' ले प्रतिस्थापन गरिन्छ, र 'to' लाई 'that' ले प्रतिस्थापन गरिन्छ, जसपछि परिणाम व्यक्त गर्ने clause आउँछ।

subQuestions.questionEnglish: He had to cancel the trip. (Change into negative.)
subQuestions.correctAnswer: He didn't have to cancel the trip.
subQuestions.explanation:
Explanation (English): 'Had to' is the past form of 'have to'. To make it negative, we use the auxiliary 'did not' (didn't) followed by 'have to'.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): 'Had to' 'have to' को भूतकाल रूप हो। यसलाई नकारात्मक बनाउन, हामी सहायक क्रिया 'did not' (didn't) पछि 'have to' प्रयोग गर्छौं।

subQuestions.questionEnglish: She visits her parents once a month. (Change into a 'How often' question.)
subQuestions.correctAnswer: How often does she visit her parents?
subQuestions.explanation:
Explanation (English): The phrase 'once a month' answers the question 'How often?'. To form the question, use 'How often' followed by the auxiliary 'does' (for a third-person singular subject in simple present), the subject 'she', and the base form of the verb 'visit'.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): 'once a month' वाक्यांशले 'कति पटक?' प्रश्नको उत्तर दिन्छ। प्रश्न बनाउन, 'How often' पछि सहायक क्रिया 'does', कर्ता 'she', र क्रियाको मूल रूप 'visit' प्रयोग गर्नुहोस्।

questions.title: Choose and copy the correct answers from the brackets to complete the given text. (Rewriting the text is not compulsory.)
questions.passage: A few years ago, our school decided to organize (a) _____ (a/an/the/no article) educational tour to Lumbini. It is (b) _____ (a/an/the/no article) sacred place for Buddhists. The students (c) _____ (were exciting/were excited/excited/exciting) about the trip. We started our journey early in the morning. (d) _____ (Although/Because/In spite of/However) the long bus ride, everyone was in high spirits. Our teacher, Mr. Sharma, told us, "You (e) _____ (must/can/may/might) stay together as a group." One of my friends asked him (f) _____ (that/if/what/when) we could take photographs. He replied that we could, but we shouldn't (g) _____ (to disturb/disturb/disturbing/disturbed) the monks. If I had known about the museum beforehand, I (h) _____ (would visit/will visit/would have visited/visit) it for sure. The trip was a great success, (i) _____ (wasn't it/was it/weren't they/did it)? It made us (j) _____ (to learn/learn/learning/learnt) so much about our country's history and culture.

gaps.explanation:
Explanation (English): 'an' is used before 'educational' because it starts with a vowel sound.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): 'educational' स्वर वर्णको ध्वनिबाट सुरु हुने भएकोले, यसको अगाडि 'an' प्रयोग हुन्छ।

Explanation (English): 'a' is used to refer to a single, non-specific sacred place.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): 'a' लाई एउटा, अविशिष्ट पवित्र स्थानलाई जनाउन प्रयोग गरिन्छ।

Explanation (English): The past participle 'excited' is used as an adjective to describe the students' feeling.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): 'excited' past participle लाई विद्यार्थीहरूको भावना वर्णन गर्न विशेषणको रूपमा प्रयोग गरिएको छ।

Explanation (English): 'In spite of' is used before a noun phrase ('the long bus ride') to show contrast.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): भिन्नता देखाउन noun phrase ('the long bus ride') को अगाडि 'In spite of' प्रयोग गरिन्छ।

Explanation (English): 'must' is a modal verb used to express strong obligation or a rule.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): 'must' एक modal verb हो जुन बलियो दायित्व वा नियम व्यक्त गर्न प्रयोग गरिन्छ।

Explanation (English): 'if' is used to introduce a reported yes/no question.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): 'if' लाई reported yes/no प्रश्न सुरु गर्न प्रयोग गरिन्छ।

Explanation (English): The modal verb 'shouldn't' is followed by a bare infinitive (verb without 'to').
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): modal verb 'shouldn't' पछि bare infinitive (verb without 'to') प्रयोग हुन्छ।

Explanation (English): This is a Type III conditional sentence (If + past perfect...), used for an unreal past condition. The result clause uses 'would have + V3'.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): यो Type III conditional वाक्य हो (If + past perfect...), जुन विगतको असम्भव अवस्थाको लागि प्रयोग हुन्छ। परिणाम खण्डमा 'would have + V3' प्रयोग हुन्छ।

Explanation (English): The subject of the statement is 'The trip' (it) and the verb is 'was' (positive). The tag is therefore negative.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): वाक्यको कर्ता 'The trip' (it) हो र क्रिया 'was' (positive) हो। त्यसैले ट्याग नकारात्मक हुन्छ।

Explanation (English): The causative verb 'made' is followed by a bare infinitive ('learn').
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): causative verb 'made' पछि bare infinitive ('learn') प्रयोग हुन्छ।
